clinical_study.brief_title: Comparing OutcomeS of Through Knee and Above Knee Amputation
clinical_study.official_title: Comparing OutcomeS of Through Knee and Above Knee Amputation (COSTAA)

lead_sponsor.agency: Hull University Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust

clinical_study.source: Hull University Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust

brief_summary.textblock: Major lower limb amputation is a life changing surgical procedure to treat complications of diabetes mellitus and peripheral vascular disease. The level of function after amputation is dependent on pre-morbid levels of activity, age, co-morbidities and the level of amputation. The level of amputation performed is determined by level of disease and surgical assessment. Below knee amputation provides the best functional outcomes due to the benefits of keeping the knee intact. When a below knee amputation is not possible, routine practice is to perform an above knee amputation. Greater challenges for rehabilitation present at this level due to the shorter lever. Amputation through the knee is less commonly performed despite its reported benefits which include a long mechanical lever arm, an endbearing stump and greater muscle control. A recent systematic review recommends further comparison of through knee and above knee amputation. The recommended areas of research are gait biomechanics and quality of life for these patient groups. Therefore the aim of this research is to compare and contrast the long term biomechanical and quality of life outcomes of limb wearing through knee and above knee amputees. The study will be split into two workstreams, the first focusing on gait biomechanics and the second focusing on quality of life using semi-structured interviews.

primary_outcome.measure: The primary outcomes measure for workstream 1 is walking velocity.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Measures taken at baseline visit, data reported through study completion, an average of 1 year
primary_outcome.description: Walking velocity will be calculated as time in seconds during stair climbing, obstacle crossing and two minute walk test (2MWT). Markers positioned on the body will be tracked through a motion capture software and analysed.

primary_outcome.measure: The primary outcome measure for workstream 2 is an in-depth analysis and comparison of quality of life.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 1 year
primary_outcome.description: The analysis of semi-structured interviews and focus groups using a self designed topic guide with questions relating to quality of life.

secondary_outcome.measure: The secondary outcome measures for workstream 1 include step length.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measures taken at baseline visit, data reported through study completion, an average of 1 year
secondary_outcome.description: Step length is recorded using markers positioned on the body and is calculated as the distance between the left and right foot placement in centimetres. Measurements will be taken during two minute walk test (2MWT) and obstacle crossing trials.

secondary_outcome.measure: The secondary outcome measures for workstream 1 include stride length.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measures taken at baseline visit, data reported through study completion, an average of 1 year
secondary_outcome.description: Stride length is recorded using markers positioned on the body and is calculated as the distance between the first left and repeated left foot placement in centimetres. Measurements will be taken during two minute walk test (2MWT) and obstacle crossing trials.

secondary_outcome.measure: The secondary outcome measures for workstream 1 include joint forces.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measures taken at baseline visit, data reported through study completion, an average of 1 year
secondary_outcome.description: Joint forces will be calculated as the amount of pressure recorded in newtons on the kistler force plates during 2MWT, obstacle crossing, stair climbing, sit-to-stand and seated postural tests.

secondary_outcome.measure: The secondary outcome measures for workstream 1 include musculoskeletal contractions and activation.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measures taken at baseline visit, data reported through study completion, an average of 1 year
secondary_outcome.description: Muscle activation will be calculated by using skin surface electrodes as part of electromyography (EMG). Measurements will be recorded as an EMG amplitude voltage (in mV or Î¼V).

secondary_outcome.measure: The secondary outcome measures for workstream 1 include trunk lean and postural control outcomes.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measures taken at baseline visit, data reported through study completion, an average of 1 year
secondary_outcome.description: Trunk lean and postural control will be recorded as range of motion in degrees. Markers positioned on the body will be tracked through a motion capture software.

secondary_outcome.measure: The secondary outcome measures for workstream 1 include recording of confidence levels using the Activity-Balance Confidence (ABC-UK) questionnaire.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measures taken at baseline visit, data reported through study completion, an average of 1 year
secondary_outcome.description: Confidence levels will be calculated using the Activity-Balance Confidence (ABC-UK) questionnaire. Items are rated on a scale 0-100, 0 represents no confidence and 100 represents complete confidence when performing activities.

secondary_outcome.measure: The secondary outcome measures for workstream 1 include confidence levels using the Locomotor-Capabilities Index-5 (LCI-5) questionnaire.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measures taken at baseline visit, data reported through study completion, an average of 1 year
secondary_outcome.description: Confidence levels will be calculated using the Locomotor-Capabilities Index-5 (LCI-5) questionnaire. Items are scored on a 4 point scale ranging from 0 = not able to accomplish activity alone 3= being able to accomplish the activity alone.

secondary_outcome.measure: The secondary outcome measures for workstream 1 include confidence levels using the Short Form Survey Instrument (SF36)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measures taken at baseline visit, data reported through study completion, an average of 1 year
secondary_outcome.description: Confidence levels will be calculated using the Short Form Survey Instrument (SF36). Items are scored using Likert scale and yes/no options. Scales are standardised with a scoring algorithm to obtain a score ranging from 0-100. High scores indicate better health status.

secondary_outcome.measure: The secondary outcome measures for workstream 1 include confidence levels using Houghton's Scale of Prosthetic Use.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measures taken at baseline visit, data reported through study completion, an average of 1 year
secondary_outcome.description: Confidence levels will be calculated using Houghton's Scale of Prosthetic Use. This is a 4 item instrument to capture prosthetic wearing habits. Users will have a total score out of 12 where a high score indicates great performance and great comfort. The first 3 items are scored on a 4 point scale ranging from 0-3 where 0=low level of confidence and 3 = high level of confidence. The 4th item is a yes/no question relating to stability where yes scores 0 and No scores 1.

secondary_outcome.measure: The secondary outcome measures for workstream 1 include confidence levels using the EuroQol EQ-5D-5L questionnaire.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measures taken at baseline visit, data reported through study completion, an average of 1 year
secondary_outcome.description: Confidence levels will be calculated using the EQ-5D-5L questionnaire. EQ-5D-5L is a standardized instrument for measuring generic health and mobility. Scores are calculated using a likert scale 1-5 to indicate levels of severity where 1 = no problems and 5 = high level of problems. The EQ-5D-5L also includes a Visual Analogue Scale (EQ-VAS) score, users rate their perception of their health on a scale of 0-100 where 0=worst and 100=best health.

secondary_outcome.measure: The secondary outcome measures for workstream 2 are the lived experiences, processes of adjustment, body image, satisfaction with prosthesis and overall quality of life differences between the through knee and above knee amputees.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 1 year
secondary_outcome.description: The analysis of semi-structured interviews and focus groups using a topic guide with self-designed questions relating to the lived experiences, processes of adjustment, body image, satisfaction with prosthesis.

arm_group.description: Community dwelling individuals with through knee amputation of all mobility levels.
Community dwelling individuals with above knee amputation of all mobility levels.

intervention.description: Semi-structured interviews will be undertaken with at least 24 and up to as many as 36 through knee and above knee amputees. A topic guide will be used to interview participants about perceived functional ability, body image, adapting post amputation and overall quality of life. A sampling frame will be used to ensure a range of views are sought (e.g. both men and women with through and above knee amputations; and with different mobility levels). Thematic analysis will be used to analyse the data. Focus group discussions will be informed by the findings of the interviews. The themes that emerge from the semi-structured interviews will be further explored using focus groups and allow for comparison of the experiences between through knee and above knee amputees.

Biomechanical seated balance will be assessed in non-ambulatory (wheelchair users) individuals. This will quantify seated postural control within motion capture. Kinetic and kinematic variables will be calculated. Walking, stair climbing, obstacle crossing, seated activities and balance tests will be assessed in ambulatory (prosthetic using) individuals. Motion capture software will be used to analyse and compare kinematic and kinetic variables between the two groups. Fear of falls and confidence levels when performing tasks will be investigated using two questionnaires. The EQ-5D-5L and SF-36 will be issued to the non-ambulatory and ambulatory participants to complete when attending the testing session. The Locomotor Capability Index - 5 (LCI-5), Activities-specific Balance Confidence Scale (ABC-UK) and Houghton scale of prosthetic use in people with lower-extremity amputations

study_pop.textblock: Community dwelling adults with through knee or above knee amputation of all mobility levels.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Community dwelling adults aged 18 or over.
- People who have had either a through-knee or above-knee amputation.
- Unilateral amputees.
- English speaking and cognitively be able to follow instructions and fill out questionnaires independently.
Exclusion Criteria:
- People are unable to provide an informed consent.
- People who have a below-knee amputation.
- Unable to transfer with assistance of one.
- Unable to walk more than 5 metres (ambulatory section workstream 1 only).
- Individuals will be excluded from workstream 2 if they report another health condition with greater impact on their quality of life than their amputation.
